DOC.HEAD: Judge Limits North Testimony in Poindexter Trial
Eds: Updates with comment from Iran-Contra Committee counsel, inserting 2 grafs after 15th graf, North testified
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday placed strict limits on the prosecution's use of Oliver L. North as a witness in the Iran-Contra trial of former National Security Adviser John Poindexter. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said prosecutors ``may only elicit evidence'' from North based on statements he made before July 15, 1987, the day Poindexter began testifying on Capitol Hill before a national television audience. The restriction means the government is unable to use most of the testimony North gave at his own trial, last April, during which he frequently mentioned Poindexter, his former White House boss. However, prosecutors will be allowed to elicit evidence from North based on his testimony to Congress, which he gave prior to Poindexter's testimony, said the judge. The government also will be permitted to delve into subjects to which Poindexter did not testify. Poindexter's trial is scheduled to begin Jan. 22 on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. At a pre-trial hearing last week, North repeatedly said he was unable to separate in his mind his own experiences in the Iran-Contra affair from what he learned by watching and reading Poindexter's testimony. The judge was openly skeptical of North's contention, but said he would accept the assertion in order to protect Poindexter's rights. ``The court takes North's alleged inability to differentiate with a grain of salt,'' said Greene. ``It seems unlikely that a witness who was a major and active participant in the events themselves would be unable to distinguish between the version of events described in another's testimony.'' The court's obligations, however, require it to ``err on the side of protecting Poindexter's constitutional right not to be convicted with the use of his own testimony,'' said the judge. Greene denied Poindexter's motion to dismiss the indictment on grounds that it had been tainted by his congressional testimony, which he gave under a guarantee that it would not be used against him in court. ``The court is confident that the government's trial witnesses will testify from knowledge that is independent of the information elicited from Poindexter at the congressional hearings,'' said the judge. Greene also allowed Iran-Contra prosecutors Dan Webb and Howard Pearl to remain in the case, rejecting assertions by Poindexter that they had been tainted by exposure to his congressional testimony. Greene said neither prosecutor has any recollection of the contents of Poindexter's testimony and therefore could make no use of it. A 1972 Supreme Court ruling says the prosecution must derive all its evidence in a case from sources wholly independent of testimony a defendant gave under a grant of immunity. Greene's ruling means North will be limited in his testimony about a presidential finding which Poindexter tore up on Nov. 21, 1986. The December 1985 finding retroactively legalized a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. North testified at his trial that he watched Poindexter tear up the finding _ which relates to four of the five criminal charges against the ex-national security adviser. But North testified last week that he was certain it was the finding that was destroyed only because Poindexter admitted it in his immunized testimony on national TV. ``I think that North has snaked his way around that'' and won't have to testify at the trial about Poindexter tearing up the finding, said John Nields, former chief counsel to the House majority staff in the congressional Iran-Contra hearings. Nields said that since North did not tell the congressional committees that he saw Poindexter destroy the finding, he ``won't be able to testify to it at the trial'' and ``I don't think the government has any other proof of it.'' The prosecution says the finding which Poindexter destroyed is ``the most critical document in proving the falsity'' of another document, a chronology which is an essential part of the government's case against Poindexter. Poindexter is accused of telling Congress the same day he destroyed the finding that no one in the U.S. government knew until 1986 that the November 1985 shipment to Iran contained Hawk missiles. py
